huron  municipal code ____________ a codification of the general ordinances of huron south dakota ____________ republished by municipal may 2009 ____________ > preface the huron south dakota municipal originally published by book publishing company in 196 has been kept current by regular supplementation by matthew bender & company inc its successor in interest this republished by municipal in may 2009 during original codification the ordinances were compiled edited and indexed by the editorial staff of book publishing company under the direction of the city attorney the organized by subject matter under an expandable threefactor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions each section number designates in sequence the numbers of the title chapter and section thus located in of title 2 in most instances sections are numbered by tens 010 020 030 etc leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions similarly chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion in parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section this legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table following the text of the listing by number all ordinances their subjects and where they appear in the codification  and beginning with the 2009 republication legislation can be tracked using the table and disposition list a subjectmatter index with complete crossreferencing locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers this supplement brings the todate number 21991874 passed  municipal capital circle sw tallahassee fl 32310 8002622633 how to use your code this code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials city employees and private citizens please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code numbering system the numbering system is the backbone of a ordinances  municipal uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this is based on three tiers beginning with title then chapter and ending with section each part is represented in the code section number for example in of title 2 title a title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled this code contains about 15 to 20 titles for example the first title is title 1 general provisions which may contain ordinances about the general penalty code adoption and definitions the titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference some titles are reserved for later use deal with more specific subjects and are often derived from one ordinance all of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title the chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material for example city manager can be added between 204 city council and city attorney section of the code contains substantive ordinance material the sections are numbered by tens to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering note at the end of each code section you will find an ordinance history note which lists the underlying ordinances for that section the ordinances are listed by number section if applicable and year example  1992 beginning with the 2009 republication a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end these history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index disposition table to find a specific ordinance in the code turn to the section called tables for the disposition table this very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code the table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance if the ordinance is codified the chapter or chapters will be indicated example 204 612 904 if the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified such as budgets taxes annexations or rezones the disposition will be special if the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code usually at the direction of the municipality the disposition will be not codified other dispositions sometimes used are tabled pending number not used or missing beginning with the 2009 republication this table will be replaced with the table and disposition list table and disposition list beginning with the 2009 republication a table and disposition list has been added for use in tracking legislative history located in the back of this volume this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification the table and disposition list specifies the ordinance number adoption date description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance by use of the table and disposition list the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein index if you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code start with the index this is an alphabetical multitier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference and crossreferences where necessary look for the main heading of the subject you need then the appropriate subheadings business license see also business tax fee  required when  the index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended instruction sheet each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an instruction sheet the instruction sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement it will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current removed pages should be kept for future reference electronic submission in the interests of accuracy and speed we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible we can accept most any file format including word wordperfect or text files if you have a choice we prefer word any version you can send files to us as an email attachment by ftp on a diskette or cdrom electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is errorfree our email address is ords@municodecom  for hard copy send two copies of all ordinances passed to municipal po box 2235 tallahassee fl 32316 customer service if you have any questions about this code or our services please contact municipal at 18002622633 or municipal capital circle sw tallahassee fl 32310 supplement history table the table below allows users of this quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the are considered codified ordinances that are not of a 219623398 8272018 not codified supp no 16 219730234 9242018 not codified supp no 16 2198953 12102018 codified supp no 16 21991874 1 72019 codified supp no 16 title 1  general provisions code   definitions references and terms as used in this code unless the context otherwise plainly requires shall have the meanings hereinafter provided 1 person includes natural persons partnerships associations organizations and corporations 2 masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter 3 words used in the singular number include the plural  and the plural the singular 4 governing body refers to board of city commissioners of the city of huron 5 city or municipality refer to the city of huron 6 the provisions regulations restrictions requirements and prohibitions contained in this code apply to the area within the territorial limits of the city of huron unless otherwise specifically provided 7 reference to any office or officer is to an office or officer of the city of huron unless otherwise specifically provided 8 the powers conferred on an officer may be exercised by his duly authorized deputy representative or employee acting under him unless otherwise provided 9 street includes alley avenue drive boulevard and traveled road 10 lot includes tract or parcel of ground      citation of code this code may be cited as the huron municipal      numbering system each section number is divided by two decimal points the number or numbers to the left of the first decimal always indicates the title number the chapter number within the title is indicated by the two digits immediately to the right of the first decimal point the last three digit positions to the right of the second decimal indicate the section number within the title and chapter      numbering of amendments and additions insofar as practical amendments of and additions to this code may be numbered as sections chapters or titles of this code generally additions to the subject matter of a given chapter may be added as additional numbered sections of the chapter a new chapter may be added to the title to which it relates new titles may be inserted in the title arrangement where openings have been reserved      vested rights nothing in this code shall be so construed as to impair any vested right or valid obligation existing when it takes effect      franchises ordinances heretofore adopted granting any franchise rightofway easement or contract shall not be affected by this code      location of poles and wires ordinances in effect at the date of enactment of this code and relating to location of electric light telephone and telegraph poles and wires shall not be affected by this code      bonds ordinances in effect at the date of enactment of this code and providing for the issuance of bonds shall not be affected by this code      appropriations ordinances in effect at the date of enactment of this code providing for appropriations shall not be affected by this code      repeal all ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this code or relating to the subject matter of this code and in reenactment as a part of this code except as stated in this chapter are hereby repealed      publication this code shall be printed and published in book form and shall take effect as provided by law      severability should any section paragraph sentence clause or phrase of this code be declared invalid or unconstitutional for any reason the remainder of this code shall not be affected thereby  1950   penalty for violations except as in this code otherwise specifically provided any person or persons firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this code or failing to comply with any of the provisions thereof shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or by imprisonment for a period of not exceeding thirty days or by both such fine and imprisonment whenever any person shall as clerk servant agent or employee of any other person or of a firm or corporation violate any of the provisions of this code he shall be deemed guilty as a principal and shall be punished as herein provided each and every violation of the provisions of this code shall constitute a separate offense   title 2  administration and city government governing body footnotes  1  state law reference form of government and changes of form  see sdc 4504 and sdc  as amended by of session laws of 1957  for officers generally see sdc 4511  provisions for acting president when mayor unable to perform duties authorized by statutesee sdc  and  editors note prior ordinance history ords 483 826 and 949   establishment the governing body of the city shall be established by the qualified electors of the city as to the form of municipal government in the city and in accordance with the statutes of the state part 1994   duties and term of office a the duties of the governing body and its members shall be determined by the form of municipal government approved by the qualified electors of the city and as prescribed for the various forms of municipal government in accordance with the statutes of the state and as prescribed by the ordinances of the city b the term of office for all members of the governing board shall be four years the fouryear terms shall commence with governing board members elected in 2014 in order to effectuate the change to the number of years within a term in the 2014 municipal election one commissioner of the governing board shall be elected to a threeyear term and one commissioner shall be elected to a fouryear term in the 2015 municipal election one commissioner shall be elected to a fouryear term in the 2016 municipal election one commissioner and the mayor shall be elected to fouryear terms and in 2017 one commissioner shall be elected to a fouryear term the effective date of this provision is  part 1994    compensation the compensation for the governing body and its members shall be set forth in the adopted certified pay schedule of the city and shall be provided for by the annual governing board budget and annual appropriation ordinance of the city part 1994   regular board meetings the board of commissions of the city shall meet in regular meetings at the hour of fivethirty pm on monday of each week at city hall except that if the regular meeting day has been deemed a legal holiday pursuant to g the weekly meeting shall not be held unless otherwise scheduled if there is no quorum present the regular meeting shall be adjourned until the next day at the same time and place   part 1994   special meetings under the mayor and four commissioner form of municipal government special meetings may be called by the mayor or by any two commissioners the special meeting notice shall be written and must state the place date and time of said special meeting and must also state the purpose and matters that will be considered at said special meeting such notice shall be given to each member of the board and a signed copy of such notice by each member of the board present at said special meeting shall be filed with and become an official part of such special meeting proceedings no other matter than the matter stated in the notice of the special meeting shall be considered at such special meeting part 1994   notice of special meetings the city finance officer shall issue a written notice for each special meeting stating by what authority the meeting is called and stating the place time date purpose and matter or matters to be considered such notice shall be served by the police department personnel upon each member of the governing body then in the city at least two hours before the hour specified for such meeting provided however that if all members of the governing body are present at the meeting place prior to the hour specified for such meeting no notice thereof shall be required to be delivered to each member in lieu thereof a copy of such notice signed by all board members present shall be filed as stated in part 1994   mayors appointments a it shall be the mayors duty to make all appointments with the approval of a majority vote of the governing body to the following appointed boards commissions and committees city parks and recreation board city planning commission city board of library trustees city safety council city board of appeals city airport board electrical board civil service board community improvement commission firemens pension board golf course commission housing & redevelopment board lake & riverfront committee correction center management committee and any other board commission or committee that may be established hereafter b all appointments shall commence on june first and expire on may thirtyfirst unless the appointment is a replacement appointment for a formerly appointed appointee part 1994   acting mayor in the event the mayor is unable to perform the duties of his office by reason of absence or sickness the members of the governing body shall appoint by a majority vote of all members thereof one of its members to act in the mayors absence or sickness whose official title shall be acting mayor of the governing board the member so appointed shall be invested with all the powers and perform all the duties of the mayor during such sickness or absence part 1994   oath of office and loyalty oath any person elected as a member of the governing body at an annual or special city election shall before assuming his official duties as a member of the governing body be duly sworn in by an official of the city government and be required to take and subscribe an oath or affirmation of office and a loyalty oath as required by the statutes of the state part 1994 officers and employees footnotes  2  editors note prior history ords 134 118 117 117 113 826 483 state law reference appointment of officers there shall be appointed by the governing body of the city on the first monday of may every year a finance officer deputy finance officer city administrator chief of police and deputy chief of police city engineer volunteer fire chief and such other appointive officers as may be provided by ordinance which appointments shall be by majority vote of the mem bers of the duly elected governing body and who shall hold office until the first monday of may of each year following their appointment or until their successors have been appointed and qualified as determined at a regular meeting of the governing body and by a majority vote of all members of the governing body part 1996   bond and oaths of appointive officers all appointive officers before entering upon the discharge of their duties shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation of office and sign a loyalty oath as prescribed by the statutes of the state of south dakota and furnish bond in the required sum conditioned upon the faithful performance of their duties and to pay over and deliver all money and property coming into their hands by virtue of their office functions according to law which bonds shall be subject to approval by the governing body such bond shall cover the period of appointment and be subject to renewal on an annual basis part 1996   officers and employees salaries the salaries of all appointive officers employees regular or parttime travel allowance and other pertinent items related to pay and allowance shall be provided for by resolution or in the annually adopted certified pay schedule of the city such salaries and allowances shall be provided for in each departments annual budget and be provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance of the city salaries of all city personnel shall be paid in accordance with a resolution adopted by the governing body relative to pay periods part 1996    duties of appointive officers all appointive officers shall perform all the duties of their offices and department functions as prescribed by statutes of the state of south dakota and such other duties as may from time to time be prescribed by ordinances of the city of huron or as directed by the governing board and members thereof which are not defined in this chapter part 1996   city finance officers duties the city finance officer is the official recording officer of the city of huron and has the custody of all official documents and records not assigned to some other officer he shall attend all meetings of the governing body and keep a record of all official proceedings he shall draw and countersign all bonds warrants and keep an accurate account of the citys indebtedness countersign all contracts certificates of work ordinances and official documents of the city he shall keep an accurate record of all receipts into the various cash funds and various departments as to function activity character and object he shall audit adjust and countersign all claim vouchers against all city departments and accounts before being presented to the governing board he shall audit and compile the various department payrolls into a combined city payroll certify all delinquent special assessment payments to the beadle county auditors office annually and keep an accurate record of all special assessment roll payments he shall compile a proposed budget and appropriation ordinance for the next fiscal year based on available cash on hand anticipated revenue and taxing ability of the city before being presented to the governing body for adoption he shall supervise the accounting system or records for all departments and officers of the city in accordance with the recommendations of the state department of audits and accounts as of december 31st each year he shall compile a report showing the financial condition of the city he shall conduct and supervise all city annual and special elections he shall issue all city licenses and permits as prescribed by city ordinances he shall safeguard and keep the official seal of the city and perform as secretary to the various boards and commissions of the city he shall prepare official documents such as notice to bidders notice of all public hearings city election notices and proceedings ordinances resolutions official minutes and perform such other administrative duties of the office and its functions the city finance officer shall receive and keep an accurate account by funds of all cash including taxes licenses permit fees fines special assessments water bills and all other income from all sources for the city of huron he shall keep an accurate bond and interest record he shall call in and provide payment for all general obligation revenue and special assessment bonds and interest coupons when due or callable keep an accurate record and account of all special assessment roll payments and send out special assessment roll notices when annual special assessment payments are due he shall collect all fees and issue receipts for all licenses permits water bills special assessments material or damage billings fines rentals parking meters municipal court and all other miscellaneous revenues he shall process all parking meter money collections for proper bank depositing he shall supervise water meter billing cutoffs new service accounts water meter deposits water meter sales and service he shall compile daily reports on bank cash balances monthly report of all cash receipts and disbursements by funds he shall allocate all revenues and receipts into their proper and assigned funds in accordance with and in the designated sum or percentage as authorized by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city of huron he shall maintain adequate collateral for the city bank accounts and perform such other duties that are required by the functions of the office or may be prescribed by ordinance or by direction of the governing body part 1996   city attorneys duties the city attorney at request of the governing body or any officer of the city shall furnish an opinion on any matter relating to the affairs of the city or the duties of any city officer he shall conduct the prosecution for violation of all city ordinances represent the city in all court actions and perform other professional services related to his office as requested by the governing body he shall attend all regular and special meetings of the governing body and attend regular and special meetings of all other city boards commissions and committees when requested and necessary he shall prepare any ordinance resolution or legal document requested by the governing body review all ordinances resolutions contracts bonds leases agreements and other legal documents to ascertain whether or not they are in legal and proper form and cover the subject matter intended and act as legal advisor for all departments within the city municipal government part 1996   city planners duties the city planner shall be directly responsible to the mayor and shall organize the efforts of his office as so ordered by the mayor he shall perform any and all duties requested of him by the urban renewal agency he shall act as the secretary of the planning and zoning commission and perform all duties required as such but shall not be a member thereof as the duly appointed and acting secretary of the planning and zoning commission he shall be the zoning administrator and perform the duties of said zoning administrator as provided in he shall work with and shall be under the direction of the planning and zoning commission of the city part 1996   duties and responsibilities of city administrator the city administrator shah provide medium term and long term planning and coordination of all services provided by the city of huron he shall submit recommendations to the city commission with facts and advice on matters of policy as a basis for making decisions and setting community goals for the future of huron he shall administer hurons comprehensive plan advise the city commission on future needs of the city and inform the community on municipal affairs he shall provide advice and assistance to the city commission and department heads on changing federal and state regulations affecting municipal services he shall provide liaison to the city planning commission and housing and redevelopment commission he shall encourage communications between the citizens of huron and municipal officials he shall emphasize friendly and courteous service to the public he shall seek improvement in the quality and image of municipal services and he shall complete special projects or duties as assigned by the city commission part 1996   destruction of records the city finance officer is authorized at his discretion in accordance with the statutes of the state of south dakota to destroy duplicate water bills paid claim vouchers cancelled and paid warrants duplicate city treasurer receipts duplicate treasurers special assessment tax receipts poll books voters registration lists and miscellaneous petitions not pertaining to public improvements obsolete insurance policies licenses and permit bonds reports requests and miscellaneous items not required for permanent record purposes by the city may be destroyed within a reasonable time after they have served their intent and purpose part 1996 wards and election precincts footnotes  3  cross reference division into wards  see sdc    boundaries of wards and precincts the city of huron is divided into election precinct except as otherwise provided and each ward within the city has only one voting precinct  as amended by    continuity of government footnotes  4  note authorized by session laws of 1961   short title this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the continuity of government the city of huron south dakota      definitions as used in this chapter unless the context otherwise clearly indicates unavailable shall mean either that a vacancy in office exists and there is no deputy authorized to exercise all of the powers and discharge the duties of the office or that the lawful incumbent of the office including any deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an office because of a vacancy and his duly authorized deputy are absent or unable for physical mental or legal reasons to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office attack shall mean any attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the united states causing or which may cause substantial damage or injury to civilian property or persons in the united states in any manner by sabotage or by the use of bombs missiles shellfire or atomic radiological chemical bacteriological or biological means or other weapons or processes duly authorized deputy shall mean a person who is presently authorized to perform all of the functions exercise all of the powers and discharge all of the duties of an office in the event the office is vacant or at such times as it lacks administration due to the death absence or disability of the incumbent officer emergency interim successor shall mean a person designated pursuant to this chapter for possible temporary succession to the powers and duties but not the office of a city officer in the event that such officer or any duly authorized deputy is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office      emergency interim successorsdesignation status qualifications and terms a elective officers within thirty days after first entering upon the duties of his office the mayor each member of the governing body and the municipal judge of this city shall designate such number of emergency interim successors to his office and specify their rank in order of succession so that there will be not less than three nor more than seven emergency interim successors for the office b appointive officers the governing body shall within the time specified in subsection a of this section in addition to any duly authorized deputy designate for appointive officers including the chief of police fire chief city auditor city treasurer city attorney city engineer city assessor and city health officer such number of emergency interim successors to these officers and specify their rank in order of succession after any duly authorized deputy so that there will be not less than three nor more than seven duly authorized deputies or emergency interim successors or combination thereof for each officer c review of designations the incumbent in the case of those elective officers specified in subsection a of this section and the governing body in the case of those appointive officers specified in subsection b of this section shall review and as necessary promptly revise the designations of emergency interim successors to insure that at all times there are at least three such qualified emergency interim successors or duly authorized deputies or any combination thereof for each officer specified d qualifications no person shall be designated or serve as an emergency interim successor unless he may under the constitution and statutes of this state and the ordinances of this city hold the office of the person to whose powers and duties he is designated to succeed but no provision of any ordinance prohibiting an officer or employee of this city from holding another office shall be applicable to an emergency interim successor e status of emergency interim successor a person designated as an emergency interim successor holds that designation at the pleasure of the designator provided that he must be replaced if removed he retains this designation as emergency interim successor until replaced by another appointed by the authorized designator      emergency interim successorsassumption of powers and duties if in the event of attack any officer named in subsections a and b of this chapter and any duly authorized deputy is unavailable his emergency interim successor highest in rank in order of succession who is not unavailable shall except for the power and duty to appoint emergency interim successors exercise the powers and discharge the duties of such officer any emergency interim successor shall exercise these powers and discharge these duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or any duly authorized deputy or an emergency interim successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises or resumes the exercise of the powers and discharge of the duties of the office or until where an actual vacancy exists a successor is appointed to fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified as provided by law      recording and publication the name address and rank in order of succession of each duly authorized deputy shall be filed with the city auditor and each designation replacement or change in order of succession of an emergency interim successor shall become effective when the designator files with the city auditor the successors name address and rank in order of succession the city auditor shall keep on file all such data regarding duly authorized deputies and emergency interim successors and it shall be open to public inspection      formalities of taking office at the time of their designation emergency interim successors shall take such oath and do such other things if any as may be required to qualify them to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which they may succeed      quorum and vote requirements in the event of an attack 1 quorum requirements for the governing body shall be suspended and 2 where the affirmative vote of a specified proportion of members for approval of an ordinance resolution or other action would otherwise be required the same proportion of those voting thereon shall be sufficient    title 3  personnel personnel regulations footnotes  1  editors note necessary in the opinion of the city commission to lay off employees all probationary seasonal and parttime employees in the affected departments shall be laid off before any full time personnel in that department are laid off after all probationary seasonal and parttime employees in the department are laid off and if it is necessary to lay off one 1 or more fulltime employees the fulltime employees shall be laid off after review and consideration of the following factors continuous length of employment in the city length of employment within the department performance evaluations licenses and certifications training and work experience after consideration of the factors should it be determined that two 2 employees in the department have equal qualifications the city shall layoff the department employee with the least seniority in the department fulltime employees who are laid off pursuant to this provision shall be placed on layoff status and entitled to recall privileges layoff status and recall privileges do not apply to probationary seasonal and parttime employees who are laid off pursuant to this provision b any employee whose job is eliminated will be placed on a lay off status in accordance with the terms of this section i recall rights shall exist for a period of one 1 year from the date of layoff ii an employee on layoff status shall be recalled to employment provided the person can perform at the time notice of recall is issued the essential job functions for the position to which recall is issued should two 2 or more persons on layoff status be able to perform the essential job functions for the position the person on layoff status having the longest consecutive years of employment with the city shall be recalled iii any laid off employee who fails to accept a full time position within seven 7 days after receiving written notice of recall will lose all seniority rights and forfeit all rights to be recalled by the city iv any person on layoff status who is not eligible for recall pursuant to subsection ii above may apply for an open position v a laidoff employee shall be responsible for keeping the city informed in writing as to hisher current address    disciplinary action and discharge a disciplinary action may include oral reprimand written reprimand suspension without pay or dismissal no employee shall be disciplined or discharged without just cause if just cause is determined disciplinary action shall be reasonably related to the seriousness of the offense and the past record b before an employee may be disciplined for unsatisfactory work performance he shall be given notice in writing outlining the areas of work performance that must be improved the employee will then have a minimum of thirty 30 working days to improve the performance before further action is taken if after thirty 30 days the work performance has not improved the employer may take such action as may be determined appropriate including suspension or dismissal c in the event by reason of unsatisfactory performance or for any other just cause the employer may suspend or dismiss any employee and will within five 5 days after taking such action notify the employee of the specific reasonss for such action and will advise the employee of his right to appeal such action under of this title d the hearing may at the employees request be open to the public the civil service boards decision shall be binding upon both the employee and the employer e just causes for dismissal or suspension without pay include but are not limited to those areas listed in this subsection any employee may be given lesser disciplinary treatment than suspension without pay or dismissal 1 theft from the employer  2 in possession of or being under the influence of alcohol or an illegal drug while on the job blood breath or chemical test showing alcohol or illegal drugs within a persons system is prima facie evidence that the individual is under the influence of alcohol or illegal drugs  3 insubordination which includes but is not limited to refusal to do the work as directed lying and disrespect shown to any other city employee including department heads and disrespect shown to a member of the governing board or to the public  4 neglect of duty neglect of duty means intentionally not doing assigned job tasks  5 willful destruction of the employers property  6 absence without leave  7 conviction of a felony including a suspended imposition of sentence  8 sexual harassment of another individual while at work f nothing in be interpreted to mean that the city has relinquished its statutory rights of an employment at will employment relationship    employee indictmentconviction should an employee be indicted by a grand jury or bound over for trial after a preliminary hearing on a felony charge the employee shall be suspended without pay pending the outcome of the criminal proceedings should the employee be convicted of a felony offense the employees employment shall be terminated a conviction for purposes of this provision includes a suspended imposition of sentence should the felony charge be dismissed or the employee found not guilty of the charges the employee shall be reinstated and the employee shall receive back pay and benefits up to a maximum of fortyfive 45 working days    abolition of position neither this chapter nor any rule hereafter adopted to carry out its provisions shall prevent the governing body from discontinuing any employment or abolishing any position or office when in the opinion of the governing body it is in the interest of the city to do so    reserved editors note adopted dec 31 201 repealed   which pertained to health insurance for retired city employees and current map for purposes of this provision the five 5 mile limit shall include the full quarter section the five 5 mile limit line passes b for good cause shown by an employee or applicant for employment the city commission may grant an exception to the residency requirement upon such conditions as may be approved by the city commission c inclement weather shall not be a justifiable reason for employees who live outside city limits to be tardy or absent from work    uniforms and protective equipment uniforms safety or protective clothing will be provided by the employer at no cost to an clothing such as jacketsglovesboots etc for employees  civil service organization   department of civil service created there shall be in the city government a department of civil service in the department there shall be a civil service board consisting of three members part 1981  1950   civil service board powers and duties powers and duties of the board shall be to formulate and administer rules and regulations providing for the selection and discharge or discipline of covered employees all rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the governing body part 1981  1950   appropriations adequate annual appropriations shall be made to enable the department to carry out effectively the provisions of this title and the governing body shall determine the amount to be so appropriated part 1981    1950   organization of board a appointmenttermqualifications 1 the civil service board shall consist of three members to be selected and appointed in the following manner one member shall be selected by the governing body and one member shall be selected by the city employees the two abovementioned members after being selected shall be approved by the governing body and when so approved the two members shall select a third member the third member selected shall also be approved by the governing body the three abovementioned selectees shall then be duly appointed members of the civil service board by the governing body the members of the civil service board shall be qualified electors of the city for a period of at least two years immediately prior to the effective date of appointment and shall believe in the merit system of employment no member of the board shall be a member of any local state or national committee of a political party or an officer or member of a committee in any partisan or political club or organization or shall hold or be a candidate for any elective public office 2 one member shall be appointed every two years effective july 1st to serve for a term of six years or until his successor has been appointed and qualified vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the same manner as original appointment 3 members may be removed by the mayor with the approval of the governing body for incompetency dereliction of duty malfeasance or other good cause and after notice and public hearing 4 the civil service board shall serve without pay b quorumtime of meetings 1 two members of the board shall constitute a quorum 2 it shall elect one of its members chairman 3 the board will meet as needed to carry out its functions 4 all meetings of the board shall be open to the public except those meetings relating to personnel matters when the employee affected requests the meetings to be closed part 1981  1950   secretary and chief examiner a appointment the civil service board shall appoint and may remove a secretary and chief examiner all of the administrative and executive powers and duties of the civil service department shall be vested in the secretary and chief examiner subject to approval by the board to be administered by him under rules which have been adopted in accordance with this title he shall have charge of applications for employment and examination of all applicants for positions he shall be the custodian of all civil service records and shall be the person upon or with whom all notice of requests for hearings complaints and other official documents relating to the civil service system shall be served or filed b belief in merit system the secretary and chief examiner shall be in sympathy with the application of merit principals and scientific methods to public employment part 1981  1950   officers and employees coveredexceptions officers and employees shall be selected and complaining employee or employees b grievance means a complaint by an employee or group of employees based upon misinterpretation or inequitable application of any existing policies rules or regulations of the city as they apply to conditions of employment c grievance procedure means the procedure set out by this chapter d supervisor means the party who is directly in charge of the aggrieved employee part 1981 part 1973   procedure a the aggrieved employee will discuss the grievance with his supervisor b if discussion has failed to resolve the grievance the employee or his representative shall within ten calendar days submit to the head of his department a written notice outlining the grievance the written grievance shall state specifically the events causing the grievance relief sought and all actions taken by the employee to resolve it the department head shall within seven calendar days of the receipt of the written grievance meet with the employee and any other individuals deemed appropriate the department head shall have seven calendar days from the meeting to render a decision in writing c should the department head not reply or the employee feels the grievance is not resolved the employee may within ten calendar days after the receipt of the decision make a written request to the mayor or his designee such request will outline those factors of the grievance that he feels have not been equitably resolved within ten calendar days of the receipt the aggrieved employee the mayor or his designee shall meet with the employee to discuss the grievance the mayor or his designee shall have ten calendar days from this meeting to render a written decision failure to comply with the tenday limitation shall constitute the resolution of the grievance in favor of the employee d in cases of discipline or discharge within fourteen days after the receipt of the decision in subsection c of this section the employee may request a hearing before the civil service board for a determination of whether the discipline or discharge is justified the hearing at the employees request may be open to the public the civil service boards decision shall be binding upon both the employer and employee part 1981 part 1973 police department   establishment the police department of the city shall consist of a chief of police deputy chief of police detectives juvenile officers and such patrolmen as from time to time may be deemed necessary by the governing body  provided however that the chief of police and commissioner of public safety may appoint extra temporary policemen in cases of emergency    1950   appointment of police on the first monday in may of each year the governing body shall appoint a chief of police and a deputy chief of police      1950    duties of chief of police the chief of police shall see that the ordinances of the city are strictly enforced he shall at all times be subject to and obey the orders of the commissioner of public safety and perform such other additional duties and orders as the governing body may prescribe and shall have supervision over the other members of the police department  1950   duties of deputy chief of police the deputy chief of police in the absence of the chief of police shall carry out the assigned duties of the appointed chief of police he shall at all times be subject to and obey the orders of the chief of police the commissioner of public safety and perform such other additional duties and orders as the chief of police commissioners of public safety and the governing body may prescribe and shall have supervision over the other members of the police department in the absence of the chief of police    conduct of police other members of the police department shall be under the supervision of the chief of police and shall obey all orders rules and regulations prescribed by the commissioner of public safety or the chief of police and shall when on duty wear the insignia of their office on their outer garments in a conspicuous place except when occasion required that it not be exposed they shall be quiet civil and orderly in their conduct and deportment and refrain from violent profane obscene and insolent language and abstain from intoxicating liquors insubordination and dereliction of duty and any violation of this section shall be reported to the commissioner of public safety and to the governing body by the chief of police immediately upon obtaining knowledge thereof  1950    duty to enforce traffic laws it shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of the traffic ordinances existing and in force in the city officers of the police department are authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal in conformance with the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city provided that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic ordinance  1950   traffic regulations the commissioner of public safety is empowered to make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the ordinances of the city relating to traffic and to make temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special condition provided any such regulations are not inconsistent with the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city  1950  retirement system all fulltime employees to participate in sdrs   1963    contributions the finance officer is directed to deduct mandatory percentages and forward same to the retirement system  said deductions to be rules and regulations adopted and established by the board of trustees of sdrs    1963  fire department footnotes  2  editors note adopted  amended ch 316 in its entirety to read as herein set out shall keep a record of all arrests and investigations  b in cases of fire to establish limits wherein no person or persons shall be allowed to come except firefighters officers of the law and the owners of property within the limits so prescribed  c to summon any public or private conveyance to his assistance to haul or convey fire apparatus to a fire and in emergencies to call any citizen to aid the fire department in extinguishing a fire  d unless the city has entered into a governmental agreement with another governmental entity which authorizes the fire chief to permit fire engines ladder truck and fire department personnel to leave the city of huron the public safety commissioner must give consent for the fire engines ladder truck and fire department personnel to leave the city fire department officer in command in extinguishing the fire or in removing and protecting property any member of the fire department failing or refusing to obey the command of the officer in charge shall be subject to disciplinary action including termination of employment any member of the volunteer fire department failing or refusing to obey the command of the officer in charge may have his or her authorization as a volunteer fire fighter for the city of huron revoked by the huron city commission c no employee of the huron fire department or volunteer fire fighter may leave the fire both such fine and imprisonment    roller skating rinks footnotes  4  state law reference municipalities specifically authorized to license tax regulate or prohibit public skating rinkssee sdcl  93415 cross reference general licensing provisionssee ch 504 of this code  minors curfewsee ch 920 of this code   definitions a roller skating means the act of a person or persons rapidly moving or gliding over a smooth surface by means of a contrivance for the foot consisting of rollers attached to a plate or frame with suitable clamps or straps for fastening it to the sole of a boot or shoe or by other similar contrivance by which the same effect or result is obtained b public roller skating rink as used herein means any room place or space within a building or other structure in which roller skating as hereinbefore defined is conducted and to which the public generally is admitted by payment of a fee or by the purchase possession or presentation of a ticket or token or in which a charge is made for caring for clothing or other property or to which the public may gain admission with or without the payment of a fee  1950   license it is unlawful to conduct any public roller skating rink within the limits of the city until such rink or the place within which the same may be held shall first have been duly licensed for such purposes applications for licenses shall be made and presented upon forms supplied by the city auditor the license shall be signed by the mayor and city auditor and shall be posted in a conspicuous place within the hall or place in which roller skating is conducted each license granted hereunder shall expire on the first day of may succeeding the date of issue the annual license fee shall be ten dollars  1950   compliance with fire and health regulations no license for a public roller skating rink or place shall be issued until it shall be found that such rink or place complies with the ordinances health and fire regulations of the city and laws of the state  that it is properly ventilated and properly supplied with toilet conveniences and is a safe and proper place for the purpose for which it is to be used  1950   inspection governing body the information obtained in such investigation accompanied by a recommendation as to whether a license should be granted or refused no license shall be extended or renewed without the inspection and report and recommendation of the officers named herein as above provided  1950   revocation of license the license of any public roller skating rink shall be forfeited or revoked by the is created for the purpose of funding the enhancement expansion marketing and promotion of visitor facilities events attractions and activities benefiting the city and its hotels and motels located within the district    occupational tax imposed commencing  an occupational tax in the amount of $200 per night shall be imposed upon the above hotels motels or lodging establishments based upon rooms rented to transient guests this occupation tax shall be fair equitable and uniform as to class no occupational tax may be imposed on any transient guest who has been offered a room by a lodging establishment on a complimentary basis whereby no fee or rent is charged for such room or upon any transient guest who is representing an entity which is exempt from sales tax pursuant to sdcl 104510 additionally no occupational tax may be imposed on any room utilized by a transient guest who stays twentyeight 28 or more consecutive nights this tax rate may be adjusted by the city commission in accordance with sdcl  95516 for lodging establishments which have less than 25 rooms and voluntarily participating in the occupational tax no occupational tax shall be imposed on any room utilized by a transient guest who stays seven 7 or more consecutive nights   a 1302012   duty to account for complimentary and lease rooms each hotel motel or lodging establishment shall account for complimentary or leased rooms which are also subject to audit by the city finance officer with such records to show the basis for offering such room on a complimentary or lease basis    computation and collection of occupational tax the city finance officer is authorized and directed to determine and compute the tax in accordance with this article the occupational tax assessed pursuant to the terms of this article shall be remitted to the city finance director each month no later than the last day for filing monthly state sales tax with the remittance to be for the previous calendarmonths tax collections each hotel motel or lodging establishment subject to this article shall keep accurate records of amounts collected from transient guests for review by the city finance officer or hisher designee upon request by the city finance officer    statement required along with occupational tax payment a person authorized by a business governed by this article shall sign a sworn statement to be submitted along with the remittance of any tax imposed by this article on or before the 20th day of each month stating as follows i declare under penalty of perjury that the above accounting of rooms rented is accurate and the tax payment made herein is accurate to the best of my knowledge according to my business records such statement shall include the signature of a person authorized to make such statement on behalf of the business that persons printed name and title and the date such signature is made    penalties for failure to pay occupational tax all remittances of occupancy tax collected pursuant to this article shall be due and received in the office of the city finance director each month no later than the last day for filing monthly state sales tax following the month for which the occupancy tax remittances are due all amounts that are not as set forth above will be charged a late fee in the amount of ten percent of the total amount due failure to remit such tax shall constitute a violation of this chapter which may be punishable by a fine of up to $50000 andor imprisonment for up to 30 days pursuant to the municipal unpaid balance under this article shall constitute a lien upon the property owned by the business or user of space being taxed and shall become a lien against and shall run with the property and may be enforced and collected in the same manner as other unpaid real property taxes and assessments the city finance officer shall certify all unpaid amounts or balances to the county treasurer for collection in the same manner as general property taxes are collected further the city shall have the ability to deny the issuance of permits or licenses or any renewals thereof to any business or premise that fails to conform to the provisions of this article including but not limited to building permits malt beverage licenses and liquor licenses the city shall also have the right to suspend service of municipal utilities until the delinquent occupancy tax is paid in full nothing within this provision shall be construed as limiting any other rights which the city has or may pursue in seeking collection of monies received but not paid under the terms of this article in the event that this tax becomes subject to supervision by the state states department of revenue any rights which the city has herein shall be deemed cumulative to any powers which inure to the benefit of the state in the event of any legal proceeding being initiated to seek collection of any delinquent assessments the offending hotel motel or lodging establishment shall be responsible for and pay all attorneys fees and costs incurred by the city seeking payment under the terms of this article    costs incurred by city in administering occupational tax all costs incurred by the city or the city finance officer pursuant to this article shall be paid from occupancy taxes collected under this article    payment of occupational tax commission and together with a copy of every notice and order related thereto shall be entered as a matter of public record in the office of the building inspector but the transcript of the proceedings need not be transcribed unless judicial review of the decision is sought as provided by this section any person aggrieved by the decision of the city commission may seek relief therefrom in any court of competent jurisdiction as provided by the law of the state e whenever any city inspector finds that an emergency exists which requires action to protect the public health they may without notice or hearing issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as they may deem necessary to meet the emergency including the suspension of the permit notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter such order shall be effective immediately any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately but upon petition to the city commission shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible the provisions of c and d shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter part 2000   adoption of regulations by the city commission the city commission is authorized to make and after public hearing to adopt such written regulations as may be necessary for the proper enforcement of the provisions of this chapter such regulations shall have the same force and effect as the provisions of this chapter and the penalty for violation of the provisions thereof shall be the same as the penalty for violation of the provisions of this chapter as hereinafter provided part 2000   design requirements of mobile homemanufactured home parks a general requirements condition of soil ground water level drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants the site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke noise odors or other adverse influences and no portion subject to unpredictable andor sudden flooding subsidence or erosion shall be used for any purpose which would expose persons or property to hazards b soil and ground cover requirements exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every mobile home park shall be paved or covered with other materials or protected with vegetation growth approved by the city engineer so that the same complies with the requirements of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust c site drainage requirements the ground surface in all parts of every mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe efficient manner d exterior appearance standards for mobile homesmanufactured homes in parks established after  1 the exterior wall covering shall be either a wood or masonry finish or material that appears to be wood or masonry  andor b vertically or horizontally grooved siding or lap siding or material that appears to be vertically or horizontally grooved siding or lap siding  2 the mobile homemanufactured home shall have a pitched roof  3 the roofing material of the mobile homemanufactured home shall consist of either wood shakes asphalt composition or wood shingles  clay concrete slate or metal tiles  4 the use of flat or corrugated sheet metal for the exterior walls or roof covering is prohibited e mobile homemanufactured home parks must meet location space and general layout requirements as defined in r6 mobile homemanufactured home district f any mobile homemanufactured home park established prior to  which undergoes a redesign or change to fifty percent or more of the spaces in the park shall meet the requirements of these requirements shall apply to the entire mobile homemanufactured home park part 2000   mobile homemanufactured home stands the area of the mobile homemanufactured home stand shall be improved to provide adequate support for the placement and tiedown of the mobile homemanufactured home thereby securing the superstructure against uplift sliding rotation and overturning in accordance with the following methods 1 the mobile homemanufactured home stand shall not heave shift or settle unevenly under the weight of the mobile homemanufactured home due to frost action inadequate drainage vibration or other forces acting on the structure  and 2 the mobile homemanufactured home stand shall be provided with anchors and tiedowns such as castinplace concrete dead men eyelets imbedded in concrete foundation of runways screw augers arrowhead anchors or other devices securing the stability of the mobile homemanufactured home  or 3 anchors and tiedowns shall be placed at least at each corner of the mobile homemanufactured home stand and each shall be able to sustain a minimum tensile strength of two thousand eight hundred pounds part 2000   water supply a an accessible adequate safe and potable supply of water shall be provided in each mobile homemanufactured home park capable of furnishing a minimum of two hundred fifty gallons per day per mobile homemanufactured home space the development of an independent water supply to serve the mobile homemanufactured home park shall be made only after express approval has been granted by the health officer and city engineer where a public supply of water of such quality is available connection shall be made thereto and its supply shall be used exclusively b the water system of the mobile homemanufactured home park shall be connected by pipes to all buildings and all mobile homemanufactured home spaces c all water piping shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with state and local law  the water piping system shall not be connected with nonpotable or questionable water supplies and shall be protected against the hazards of backflow or backsiphonage d where drinking fountains are provided for public use they shall be of a type and in locations approved by the health officer e individual water service connections which are provided for direct use by mobile homesmanufactured homes shall be constructed that they will not be damaged by the parking of such mobile homesmanufactured homes the mobile homemanufactured home park water system shall be adequate to provide twenty pounds per square inch of pressure at all mobile homemanufactured home connections f where an independent or nonpublic water system is used to serve the mobile homemanufactured home park with water obtained from wells the wells shall have been approved by the health officer and shall have been drilled or driven springs or other sources of supply shall not be used unless approved by the health officer part 2000   sewage disposal a all plumbing in the mobile homemanufactured home park shall comply with state and local plumbing laws and regulations b each independent mobile homemanufactured home space shall be provided with at least a threeinch sewer connection the sewer connection shall be provided with suitable fittings so that a watertight and gastight connection can be made between the mobile homemanufactured home drain and the sewer connection such individual mobile homemanufactured home connection shall be so constructed that they can be closed when not linked to a mobile homemanufactured home and shall be capped so as to prevent any escape of odor where space is provided to accommodate recreation vehicles ie camper trailers pickup trailers etc at least one station shall be provided for cleaning and flushing of holding tanks and filling of water tanks c sewer lines shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city engineer and in accordance with his recommendations all sewer lines shall be adequately vented and shall be laid with sufficient earth to prevent breakage from traffic d where the sewer lines of the mobile homemanufactured home park are not connected to a public sewer a method of sewage disposal approved by the city engineer and in accordance with state law shall be based on the maximum capacity of the mobile homemanufactured home park effluents from sewage treatment facilities shall not be discharged into any waters of the state except with prior approval of the appropriate state authority and the local health officer the disposal facilities shall be located where they will not create a nuisance or health hazard to the mobile homemanufactured home park or to the owner or occupants of any adjacent property the approval of the city engineer shall be obtained on the type of treatment proposed and on the design of the disposal plant prior to construction part 2000   refuse disposal a the storage collection and disposal of refuse in the mobile homemanufactured home park shall be so managed as to create no health hazards rodent harborage insect breeding areas accident or fire hazards or air pollution b all refuse shall be stored in flytight watertight rodentproof containers which shall be located not more than one hundred fifty feet from any mobile homemanufactured home space containers shall be provided in sufficient number and capacity to properly store all refuse and the place where the garbage and rubbish containers are located shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times on a platform or rack fifteen inches or more above the ground surface c racks or holders shall be provided for all refuse containers such container racks or holders shall be so designed as to prevent containers from being tipped to minimize spilling and container deterioration and to facilitate cleaning around them d all refuse shall be collected in accordance with existing ordinances of the city where suitable collection service is not available from municipal or private agencies the mobile homemanufactured home park operator shall provide this service all refuse shall be collected and transported in covered vehicles or covered containers e the mobile homemanufactured home park operator shall dispose of the refuse in an approved manner part 2000   insect and rodent control a insect and rodent control measures to safeguard public health as required by the health officer shall be applied in the mobile homemanufactured home park b effective larvicidal solutions may be required by the health officer for fly or mosquito breeding areas which cannot be controlled by other more permanent measures c the health officer may require the mobile homemanufactured home park operator to take suitable measures to control other insects and noxious weeds d accumulations of debris which may provide harborage for rodents shall not be permitted in the mobile homemanufactured home park e when rats or other objectionable rodents are known to be in the mobile homemanufactured home park the park operator shall take definite action as directed by the health officer to exterminate them part 2000   utilities all utility services shall be buried and shall comply with all applicable state and local codes and ordinances part 2000   fuel all piping from outside fuel storage tanks or cylinders to mobile homesmanufactured homes shall be copper or other approved tubing and shall be permanently installed and securely fastened in place all fuel storage tanks or cylinders shall be securely fastened in place and shall not be located inside or beneath the mobile homemanufactured home or less than five feet from any mobile homemanufactured home exit part 2000   modification of mobile homemanufactured home it is unlawful for any person owning or operating a mobile homemanufactured home park to modify any mobile homemanufactured home in a manner that would prevent the ready removal of such mobile homemanufactured home such alteration shall be construed as removing it from the requirements of this chapter and converting it into a dwelling and it shall be deemed to be in violation of the building code of the city part 2000   fire protection a the mobile homemanufactured home park area shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the city and the fire prevention code b mobile homemanufactured home park areas shall be kept free of litter rubbish and other flammable materials c portable fire extinguishers of a type approved by the fire administrator shall be kept in any buildings and at all other locations designated by the fire administrator and shall be maintained in good operating condition d standard fire hydrants shall be located within four hundred feet of each mobile homemanufactured home or other buildings e fires shall be made only in approved equipment intended for such purpose part 2000   restrictions of animals and pets no owner or person in charge of a dog cat or other pet animal shall permit it to run at large or to commit any nuisance within the limits of any mobile homemanufactured home park part 2000   registration of occupants a every mobile homemanufactured home park owner or operator shall maintain a register containing a record of all mobile homesmanufactured homes and occupants using the mobile homemanufactured home park such register shall be available to any authorized person inspecting the park and shall be preserved for the period required by the building inspector such register shall contain 1 the names and addresses of all mobile homemanufactured home occupants stopping in the park  2 the state territory or county issuing the mobile homemanufactured home license  and 3 the dates of arrival and departure of each mobile homemanufactured home part 2000   supervision the person to whom a permit for a mobile homemanufactured home park is issued shall at all times operate the park in compliance with this chapter rules and regulations issued thereunder and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition at all times part 2000   penalties any person who violates any provision of this chapter or any provision of any regulation adopted by the city commission pursuant to authority granted by this chapter shall upon conviction be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment for not more than thirty days and each days failure of compliance with any such provision shall constitute a separate violation part 2000   conflict of ordinanceseffect of partial invalidity a in any case where a provision in this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning building fire safety or health ordinance or code of the city existing on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter the provision which in the judgment of the health officer established the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail in any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code of the city existing on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be deemed to prevail and such other ordinances or codes are declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this chapter b if any section subsection paragraph sentence clause or phrase of this chapter should be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever such decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter which shall remain in full force and effect  and to this end the provisions of this chapter are declared to be servable all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are repealed part 2000   effective date this chapter shall be in full force and effect from and after is passage approval and publication as provided by law part 2000 pistols footnotes  7  cross reference general license provisions  see ch
