vehicle shall cross over from the right side of the street to the left side of the street or make a complete turnaround or turn of one hundred eighty degrees upon any street except on the intersection of one street with another no vehicle shall be permitted to make a complete turnaround or turn of one hundred eighty degrees at the intersection with other streets where official traffic signs indicate such is prohibited or traffic control signals are erected and placed or may hereafter be erected or placed       turning at intersections the driver of any vehicle intending to turn to the right at an intersection shall approach the intersection in the lane for traffic nearest to the right hand side of the street and in turning shall keep as closely as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the street  and when intending to turn to the left shall approach the intersection in the lane for traffic to the right of and nearest to the center line of the street and in turning shall pass to the left of the center of the intersection passing as closely as practicable to the left thereof so as to complete the turn so that such vehicle shall pass into such cross street in the lane of traffic to the right of the center of the cross street at the intersection of such streets for the purpose of this section the center of the intersection shall mean the meeting point of the medial lines of the streets intersecting one another      keep to right the driver of any vehicle shall keep to the right of the center line of the street along which he is driving the driver of a slowly moving vehicle shall keep as near the right hand curb as possible      overtaking and passing the operator of any vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall pass at a safe distance to the left thereof but only when such left side is clearly visible and is free from oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing to be made in safety and shall not cut in front of the overtaken vehicle until safely clear of same the driver of a vehicle within a business or residence district shall not deviate from his direct line of travel without ascertaining that such movement can be made with safety to other vehicles approaching from the rear the driver of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass another vehicle upon the crest of a grade upon a curve in the highway where the drivers view along the highway is obstructed for five hundred feet upon any street in a no passing zone indicated either by regulatory signs adjacent to the street or by pavement markings with a yellow line to the right of the center line  as amended by      backing no vehicle shall be backed around a corner at an intersection or into an intersection of public streets no vehicle shall be backed without ample warning first having been given and while backing care must be exercised not to injure persons or vehicles or to block traffic      overtaken vehicleslow driving the operator of a vehicle upon a street about to be overtaken and passed by another vehicle approaching from the rear shall give way to the right in favor of the overtaking vehicle on suitable and audible signal being given by the driver of the overtaking vehicle and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle no person shall drive any vehicle at an unnecessarily slow rate of speed so as to hinder and retard the traffic      starting a standing vehicle about to start shall give moving vehicles the right of way and the driver thereof shall give ample warning before so starting      right of way when two vehicles approach or enter an intersection at approximately the same time the driver of the vehicle on the left shall yield the right of way to the vehicle on the right except as otherwise provided herein the driver of any vehicle traveling at an unlawful speed shall forfeit any right of way which he might otherwise have hereunder the driver of a vehicle approaching but not having entered the intersection shall yield the right of way to a vehicle within such intersection and turning therein to the left across the line of travel of such first mentioned vehicle provided the driver of the vehicle turning left has given a plainly visible signal of intention to turn as required by law the driver of any vehicle upon a street within a business or residence district shall yield the right of way to a pedestrian crossing such street within any clearly marked crosswalk or any regular pedestrian crossing included in the prolongation of the lateral boundary lines of the adjacent sidewalk at the end of a block except at intersections where the movement of traffic is being regulated by traffic officers or traffic direction devices at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signals or police officers drivers of vehicles including those making turns shall yield the right of way to pedestrians crossing or those who have started to cross the roadway on a green or go signal and in all other cases pedestrians shall yield the right of way to vehicles lawfully proceeding directly ahead on a green or go signal every pedestrian crossing a street within a business or residence district at any point other than a pedestrian crossing crosswalk or intersection shall yield the right of way to vehicles upon the street      exceptions to right of way rule the driver of a vehicle entering a public street from an alley private road or drive shall yield the right of way to all vehicles approaching on such public street the driver of a vehicle upon a street shall yield the right of way to ambulances police and fire department vehicles when operated upon official business and the drivers of any such vehicles sound audible signal by bell siren or exhaust whistle the operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive his vehicle as near as possible and parallel to the right hand curb of the street clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in such position until such emergency vehicle shall have passed unless otherwise directed by a police officer these provisions shall not operate to relieve the driver of a police fire department vehicle or ambulance from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway nor shall it protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequence of an arbitrary exercise of such right of way street maintainers in the performance of their duties of maintaining the streets shall have the preference of right of way and shall be permitted to drive upon the left hand side of the streets for the purpose of dumping materials for repairing or smoothing the roadway or for cleaning streets and removing snow such maintainers shall at all times display a red flag of such dimensions and in such manner as prescribed by the state highway commission to indicate his identity such maintainer shall not indiscriminately block traffic but shall allow reasonable room on the traveled portion of the street for other vehicles to pass such maintainer shall not be bound by the rules herein provided to turn to the right when meeting other vehicles or allowing them to pass when his work requires him to remain on the other side of the traveled portion of the street such maintainer shall be subject to the rules of travel as provided by law except when the performance of their maintenance work requires them to do otherwise      emerging from alley or drivewaystop before entering the operator of a vehicle emerging from an alley private driveway or building into a street or entering a shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a crosswalk or crosswalk area extending across such an approach every vehicle driven from an alley into a street within the business district shall go straight across the street or shall turn to the right on coming out of such alley and go in the direction of traffic on such street      reserved editors note adopted  repealed   which pertained to u turns and traveling on the left side and derived from     yield signs the driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall slow to a speed of not more than ten miles per hour and yield rightofway to all vehicles approaching from the right or left on the intersecting street which are so close as to constitute an immediate hazard if a driver is involved in a collision at an intersection or interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a yield sign such a collision or interference shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the drivers failure to yield rightofway   1950   railroad signals whenever any person driving a vehicle approaches a vehicle to fail to bring the vehicle to a complete stop before traversing such grade crossing and it shall be the duty of the driver of such vehicle to follow and obey the direction of said signal care in driving every driver of any vehicle on any street shall drive in a careful manner and with due regard for the safety and convenience of pedestrians and other vehicles  1950   exhibition driving any person firm or corporation driving andor operating a vehicle within the city limits in such a manner that creates or causes unnecessary engine noise or tire squeal skid or slide upon acceleration or stopping  or that simulates a temporary race  or that causes the vehicle to unnecessarily turn abruptly or sway shall be guilty of exhibition driving    use of dynamic air compression brake device prohibited the use or operation of a dynamic air compression braking device on unmuffled vehicles is prohibited within the city of huron except to avoid an imminent threat to the safety of the driver or any other person  or to avoid an imminent threat to property or except when used in conjunction with a special event provided that the use or operation of dynamic air compression braking devices at the special event has received prior approval of the police commissioner and chief of police a dynamic air compression braking device is a device used on vehicles that converts the engine from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheel brakes these devices are commonly referred to as air brakes engine brakes compression brakes jacobs brakes or jake brakes violations of be punishable by a fine as set by resolution of the governing board if any ticket for a violation is not paid within seven days and a summons and complaint is filed in magistrate court based on such ticket the magistrate court fine for the violation shall be as set by resolution of the governing board in addition to establishing the fine the resolution shall authorize the payment of the fine of attorney in lieu of a court appearance      distracted driving a definitions 1 distracted driving means inattentive driving while operating a moving motor vehicle that results in the unsafe operation of the vehicle where such operation is caused by reading writing performing personal grooming interacting with pets or unsecured cargo using personal communications technologies or engaging in any other activity which causes distractions 2 handsfree accessory means an attachment addon builtin feature or addition to a mobile telephone whether or not permanently installed in a motor vehicle that when used allows the vehicle operator to maintain both hands on the steering wheel 3 mobile telephone means a cellular analog wireless or games 5 text or texting means using an electronic wireless communications device to compose or send a written message or image using a textbased communication system including communications referred duties  motorcycles   definitions as used in this chapter the following word shall mean as follows motorcycle includes motorcycles motorbikes bicycles with motor attached and all motoroperated vehicles of the bicycle or tricycle type whether the motive power be a part thereof or attached thereto and having a saddle or seat with the driver sitting astride or upon it or a platform on which the driver stands but excluding a tractor part 1967   license required no person shall operate a motorcycle on the public streets or highways without a motor vehicle drivers license or permit upon which a state testing officer has certified that such person is qualified to operate such motorcycle part 1967   reserved editors note adopted  repealed   which pertained to height of handlebars and derived from part adopted in 1967   helmet required it is unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen years to operate or ride upon a motorcycle on the public streets or highways of the city unless such person wears a protective helmet of a type approved by the south dakota commissioner of motor vehicles the commissioner is authorized and empowered to adopt rules and regulations covering the types of helmets and the specifications therefor and to establish and maintain a list of approved helmets which meet the specifications established hereunder part 1993 part 1967   muffler every motorcycle shall at all times be equipped with an adequate muffler in constant operation and properly maintained to prevent any excessive or unusual noise and no muffler or exhaust system shall be complete with a cutout bypass or similar device it is unlawful to make an alterations either by way of addition or modification of any original or stock muffler part 1967   additional riders it is unlawful for an operator or driver of a motorcycle while operating on the public streets or highways of the city to carry any other person thereon except on a seat securely fastened to the machine to the rear of the driver provided with footrests or in a sidecar attached to the motorcycle and designed with the purpose of carrying a passenger a passenger under the age of eighteen years shall wear all of the safety equipment which is required for the operator of the motorcycle part 1993 part 1967   license required for rental no dealer or person renting or loaning motorcycles shall loan or rent boulevard in such a manner as to interfere with any pedestrian thereon part 1983   care in riding 1 no person shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any public street highway or boulevard except in a careful and prudent manner and unless such person shall be capable of efficient control and operation of such bicycle nor shall any person propel or operate a bicycle upon a public street highway or boulevard carrying or permitting to be carried any other person upon such bicycle 2 no bicycle shall be ridden faster than is reasonable and proper but every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard to the safety of the operator and other persons upon the streets and highways of the city 3 persons riding or propelling any bicycle shall observe all traffic signs and stop at all stop signs 4 no bicycle shall be permitted on any street highway or boulevard of the city between thirty minutes after sunset and thirty minutes before sunrise without a headlight visible from the front thereof for not less than two hundred feet indicating the approach or presence of the bicycle which light shall be firmly attached to the bicycle and properly lighted nor without a red tail light or in lieu thereof a reflector attached to and visible from the rear of such bicycle for a distance of not less than two hundred feet 5 no person under the age of twelve years shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any street highway or boulevard in the city at night after the hour of nine pm 6 no person shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any public street highway or boulevard in the city more than two abreast 7 every person riding or propelling a bicycle upon any public street highway or boulevard in the city shall observe all traffic rules and regulations applicable thereto and shall turn only at intersections signaling for all turns ride at the righthand side of the street or highway pass to the left when passing vehicles or bicycles that are slower moving and shall pass to the right when of police and fire believes necessary and he shall promulgate such routes in writing and shall file the same with the city auditor part 1965   designation of truck routes a the following streets within and around the city of huron are designated as truck routes for trucks having a gross weight over six thousand pounds 1 west park avenue from us highway 14 to 21st street sw 2 21st street from west park avenue sw to custer avenue se 3 custer avenue from us highway 14 to 21st street se b trucks having a gross weight of over six thousand pounds per axle may deviate from the truck routes to the extent required to reach a necessary destination within the city of huron which is not located on the truck routes but to the maximum extent possible truck traffic will follow in order of priority the truck routes designated above then the principle arterials then the major collectors then the minor arterials and then other local streets as the vehicle driver attempts to make a delivery within the city the city streets identified in each classification are 1 principle arterials i us highway 14 within city limits  and ii sd highway 37 within city limits 2 major collectors i third street se and sw from west park avenue to the james river  ii market street se and sw  and iii old highway 14 3 minor arterials i west park avenue from us highway 14 to 21st street sw  ii 21st street se and sw from west park avenue to the james river  and iii lincoln avenue nw and sw from 7th street nw to 21st street sw 4 all other streets are local streets c the designated truck routes within the city of huron existing prior to the enactment and adoption of this section are no longer designated truck routes within the city of huron    truck drivers responsibilities it shall be the duty of all truck drivers within the city limits to drive and operate trucks having a gross vehicle weight of over six thousand pounds upon the routes hereinabove designated except trucks making local delivery and service calls part 1965   enforcement the chief of police and all of the officers of the police department are authorized and directed to enforce the regulations above referred to and to direct all truck drivers other than that hereinabove excepted to travel upon such truck routes part 1965   state statutes or state highway department regulations nothing in the foregoing section shall be to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in  part 1965 snowmobiles   definitions as used in this chapter unless the context otherwise requires operator means a person who operates or is in actual control of a snowmobile  snowmobile means any enginedriven vehicle of a type which utilizes sledtype runners wheels or skis with an endless belt tread or similar means of contact with the surface upon which it is operated  street means every highway and street within the city limits  owner means any person other than a lienholder having the property in or title to a snowmobile and entitled to the use or possession thereof part 1972   regulations no person shall operate a snowmobile a on the portion of any rightofway on any city street or avenue used for motor vehicle travel except the most righthand lane which is used for vehicular traffic in the same direction other than on expressways or state highways while operating on the most righthand lane as previously provided at no time may snowmobiles be operated two or more abreast snowmobiles may operate in the road ditch where expressways or state highways are so configured within the city limits  b no person shall operate a snowmobile on private property of another without the express permission to do so by the owner or occupant of said property  c no person shall operate a snowmobile on public schoolgrounds park property playgrounds slide areas recreational areas and golf courses without the express permission to do so by the proper authority  d no person shall operate a snowmobile in any manner so as to create loud unnecessary or unusual noise so as to disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons e no person shall operate a snowmobile on any public sidewalk provided for pedestrian travel or on boulevards within any public rightofway or on any alleys except that travel is permitted on alleys when traveling from a place of storage to the nearest street  f no person shall operate a snowmobile on dakota avenue from 15th street north to 21st street south or on third street from frank avenue east to lincoln avenue west or on 9th street south from lawn ridge avenue east to lincoln avenue west except to cross these streets in the shortest distance possible  g no person shall operate a snowmobile within an area bordered by market road to the north illinois avenue to the west 7th street to the south and idaho avenue to the east except under road and weather conditions as declared by the chief of police or director of civil defense to constitute emergency travel conditions authorizing use of a snowmobile or when such vehicle is necessary as an emergency vehicle to protect the health safety and welfare of any individual  h no person shall operate a snowmobile in a careless reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the safety of any person the property of any other person  i no person shall operate a snowmobile within the city limits without having such snowmobile registered as provided by south dakota state law  j no person shall operate a snowmobile on any city street alley avenue or ditch as an emergency vehicle or otherwise unless the operator shall have a valid drivers license on his person  k snowmobiles may have a maximum of one additional rider other than the driver part 2001   part 1972   exceptions to regulations notwithstanding the prohibition of this chapter the superintendent of parks and recreation shall have authority to supervise and regulate events or programs in connection with the events conducted by the parks and recreation department in which snowmobiles are used the parks and recreation director shall have the authority to designate city park areas that he shall deem available for use of snowmobiles if and when such park areas are designated twelve year olds or older can operate a snowmobile in the designated area  provided that said individual is supervised by person who has a valid drivers license on his person part 1972   equipment required all snowmobiles operated within the city shall have the following equipment a mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the noise of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for operating the vehicle and no person shall use a muffler cutout bypass or similar device on said vehicle and no person shall use a megaphone or tunedexhaust system or similar device on said vehicle  b adequate brakes in good working condition  c a safety or socalled deadman throttle in operating condition a safety or deadman throttle is defined as a device which when pressure is removed from the accelerator the throttle causes the motor to disengage from the driving track  d any snowmobile being operated during the hours of darkness shall display a lighted headlamp and taillamp in accordance with sdcl 3217 as may have been approved by the commissioner of motor vehicles at least equivalent to that required for motorcycles  e a pennant flag of red or blaze material of a size not less than twelve inches by nine inches properly attached at a height of not less than six feet from the ground level at any time when the vehicle is operated within the city limits also each snowmobile shall have a one inch strip of reflectorized material on both sides of the pennant flag covering at least threefourths the length of the flag specified part 1973  part 1972   unattended vehicles it is unlawful for the owner or operator of a snowmobile to leave or allow the snowmobile to be or remain unattended on public property while the motor is running or where the keys for starting the vehicle are left in the ignition part 1972   unlawful acts it is unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile within the city limits a during the hours from eleven pm to six am of any day  b to tow any person or thing in or on the public streets or roads or other city property except use of a rigid towbar attached to the rear of a snowmobile part 1972   exemptions a none of the aforementioned provisions of this chapter are to be construed to mean that snowmobiles are permitted to operate on any public street or road or other public property within the city for the purpose of recreation but rather the aforementioned provisions are intended to provide an exit out of the city and a return to the residence of the operator or his place of storage for the snowmobile by way of the most direct and closest route available  however those individuals who live outside the city limits shall have the right to operate snowmobiles upon the public streets and roads as provided in this chapter when such vehicle is necessary as an emergency vehicle to protect the health safety and welfare of any individual b snowmobile clubs organizations individuals or groups of snowmobiles from the region are allowed to enter the community to access services gas hotelmotel rooms food restrooms maintenance etc located in the vicinity of 18th to 21st streets along dakota avenue south and along 21st street from ohio to kansas avenues current restrictions regarding prohibition to travel on dakota avenue remain in place snowmobiles entering the community for access to services shall stay within the area bounded by 18th street swse on the north ohio avenue sw on the west and kansas avenue se on the east a groomed snowmobile path chapter shall be known and may be cited as the public shelter managers the city of huron south dakota  1963   definitions as used in this chapter the following words and terms unless the context otherwise clearly indicates shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein a national emergency means any attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the united states causing or which may cause substantial damage or injury to civilian property or persons in the united states in any manner by sabotage or by the use of bombs missiles shellfire or atomic radiological chemical bacteriological or biological means or other weapons or processes b public shelters means any structure designated by the department of civil defense as and to be used as a public shelter in the event of an enemy attack or national emergency c civil defense director means the duly appointed civil defense director of the huronbeadle county civil defense district d shelter manager means the duly appointed public shelter manager or managers as appointed by the local civil defense director e shelter use plan means the rules and regulations promulgated by the huronbeadle county civil defense district pertaining to the operation use and living conditions of a public shelter during an enemy attack or national emergency f shelter occupants means the general public who are assigned to or have by reason of an enemy attack or national emergency become occupants in any of the designated public shelters  1963   appointment and duties of public shelter manager in case of national emergency public shelter managers duly appointed by the civil defense director shall open public shelters take charge of all stocks of food water and other supplies stored in said shelter admit the public according to the citys shelter use plan and take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants  1963   authority of public shelter manager shelter manager or managers are authorized to use reasonable restraint against any occupant of a public shelter who refuses to cooperate in an orderly manner and abide by the rules and regulations which shall provide for routine living in a public shelter under emergency conditions as established by the huronbeadle county civil defense district officials  1963   penalties for violations any occupant in a public shelter living under emergency conditions who refuses to carry out the orders of the public shelter manager and his appointed staff or abide by the established public shelter rules and regulations shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or a jail sentence of not more than thirty days or by both such fine and imprisonment    1963 title 18  building permit required a no wall structure building or part of building shall be constructed or added to or any permanent fixture including heat producing appliances heating ventilating air conditioning blower and exhaust systems or conversion units thereof attached to such building until a plan or proposed work statement of the materials to be used the proposed site of such structure and name of owner of the property to be improved shall be submitted to the building inspector by the contractor builder or owner  which proposed work statement shall also state the value or cost of such improvement if the building inspector is satisfied that such proposed improvement complies with the law and city ordinances he may authorize issuing a permit for such work construction or improvement if the value or costs of the improvement for which a permit has been issued shall exceed the cost or value of the amount stated in the application for permit and the permit granted the contractor builder or owner shall furnish to the building inspector an additional statement of the cost and value of such improvement b for just cause a building permit may be denied for a location identified on the application just cause includes but is not limited to the owner of the property agent who submits the application on behalf of the owner or a contractor identified on the application as being responsible for work specified on the application 1 is in arrears on payment for any city bills such as utility bills miscellaneous bills or special assessments including nuisancerelated special assessments  or 2 at the time the application for a building permit is submitted has failed to complete work with respect to a previous building permit within the time specified for completion on the previous building permit c the building inspector may issue a building permit which shall be valid for one hundred eighty days from the date the permit is issued the applicant may in writing request an extension for good cause shown the building inspector may deny the request for an extension grant one or more extensions for an additional period not exceeding one hundred eighty days each or may refer the request for an extension to the city commission d it is unlawful for any person owner or contractor or builder to attempt to proceed with any work or improvement of any kind for which a permit is in this section required without first having obtained a permit for same e any person who proceeds with work without properly obtaining a building permit shall be required to pay a late assessment fee in addition to the required fee for the building permit the late assessment fee shall be based on the following schedule 1 if the value of the construction is zero dollars to forty thousand dollars the late assessment fee shall be fifty dollars 2 if the value of the construction is forty thousand one dollars to eighty thousand dollars the late assessment fee shall be one hundred dollars 3 if the value of the construction is eighty thousand one dollars to one hundred twenty thousand dollars the late assessment fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars 4 if the value of the construction is one hundred twenty thousand one dollars or greater the late assessment fee shall be two hundred dollars f any person owner firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars or by imprisonment in the city jail for a period not exceeding thirty days   part 2002      1950 building 706 793 and 886  and ords 970 999 100 101 101 113 114 130 1423 and 1424   electrical regulations all electrical wiring apparatus or equipment shall comply with the rules and regulations promulgated and adopted by the south dakota electrical board as provided in south dakota codified laws and the national electric edition standards of the national board of fire underwriters for electric wiring and apparatus as copyrighted by the national fire protection association 470 atlantic avenue boston massachusetts 002 which is adopted by this reference as though fully set forth herein  part 1983   inferior electrical materials prohibited every person before selling offering for sale or exposing for sale any electrical material device or appliance designed for attachment to or installation in or on any electrical circuit or system for light heat or power shall first determine if such material device or appliance is approved for installation and use in the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter no person or his agent or employee shall sell offer for sale or expose for sale any such material device or appliance which does not comply with all of the provisions of this chapter all electrical appliances or devices including materials used in installation thereof or in the installation of the necessary wiring for the utilization of electricity for light heat or power shall be only those which are approved for the purpose intended and the makers name trademark or other identification symbol shall be placed thereon together with such other markings giving voltage current wattage or other appropriate ratings as may be necessary to determine the purpose and use for which intended no person shall remove alter change or deface the makers name trademark or other identification symbol or any of the necessary rating marks required by this chapter part 1983   emergency shut off of electric current the building inspector shall have authority whenever in his opinion public safety requires it and to require any person firm or corporation using or operating any electric system to disconnect the electric current therefrom for such period of time as the building inspector may deem necessary  and the fire chief or other commanding officer of the fire department shall have authority in case of fire to have the electric current cut off from any or all wires which he knows or believes are dangerous to life and property any person firm or corporation who refuses to shut off such current in accordance with the order of the building inspector or fire chief of the fire department or his assistants who may be in authority at the fire is liable to penalty of seventyfive dollars for each and every hour during which the direction of the building inspector or fire department official shall be disregarded provided that such penalty shall not exceed the sum of five hundred dollars part 1983   approval required for service connections no person shall make connection from a source of electric energy to any electric wiring devices equipment or electrical systems for the installation of which a permit is required until a certificate of approval has been issued by the state electrical inspector authorizing such connection and the use of such wiring devices equipment or electrical systems when a certificate is issued authorizing the connection and use of temporary work such a certificate shall be issued to expire at a stated time and shall be revokable by the state electrical inspector at his discretion part 1983   approval required for service reconnections no person shall make reconnections from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring devices equipment or electrical systems which has been disconnected or ordered to be disconnected by the electrical inspector or the use of which has been ordered by the electrical inspector to be discontinued until a certificate of approval has been issued by him authorizing reconnection and use of such wiring devices equipment or electrical systems part 1983   removal of dead wires and unused poles the building inspector shall have authority to remove or cause to be removed all dead wires and unused poles and all wire and poles unlawfully erected and maintained in the streets and other public places in the city no new poles shall be erected until first obtaining the approval of and a permit for the same from the building inspector in writing this provision shall apply to such utility companies as electric power telephone cable television etc part 1983   underground wiring installations whenever the installation of electric wires underground shall be approved by the building inspector and so requested by a utility company then the person firm or corporation maintaining or using wires above ground shall take down and remove at their own expense all poles used for the support of such aboveground wires and place their conduits and conducting wires beneath the ground in conformity with the latest approved and standard methods of installation for underground wiring systems part 1983   plans and specifications to be filed it is hereafter unlawful for any person firm or corporation to lay any electrical conduits without first filing with the building inspector plans and specifications of the work to be done and obtaining a written approval of the application and a permit for such work which application so approved shall be filed in the department of building inspections for record purposes part 1990 part 1983   excavation in public places nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as canceling the necessity of securing excavating permits prior to any excavations in public places as required by ordinance  nor as canceling the requirements for approval of working excavating plans for the proposed wiring installation project for which a permit is being requested from the building inspector part 1983   examination of applications for wiring projects the building inspector shall examine every application for the erection of poles or towers for the support of wires in or over any street or public place or for conduits under any street or public place for such wires and he shall report to the governing body any facts which in his opinion bear upon the question of granting or refusing to grant such application part 1983   furnishing information and location of facilities upon the request of the building inspector the person firm or corporation operating electric or other wire systems upon over or under any street or building shall within fifteen days thereafter furnish accurate drawings showing the locations of their poles and the number of crossarms thereto affixed and the number of wires thereto attached  the location of subways manholes and other pertinent information related to the completed project together with the location where service is rendered viz telegraphic telephonic electric lighting cable television or for electric power systems part 1983   permanent rights not granted all wires used within the city for the purpose of carrying an electric current shall be subject to the following conditions no permanent rights shall be obtained in the streets or public grounds by the reason of such use and such wires shall be subject to change of location or removal when deemed necessary  and in case of fire if necessary such wires may be cut or removed by order of the building inspector or officers in command of the fire department without claims against the municipality therefor part 1983   inspectors authority in abnormal cases the building inspector shall decide all questions pertaining to the installation of electric wires equipment and devices construction and installation of electrical appliances  see sdc 57 cross reference electrical wiring and apparatussee ch 1816 of this code   definitions unless otherwise expressly stated whenever used in this chapter the following words shall have the meaning given to them by this section a air conditioning means the cooling or dehumidification or both of space for human occupancy b ton of refrigeration means the heat required to melt ice at the rate of one ton in twentyfour hours one compressor horsepower shall be considered equivalent to one ton of refrigeration c installed capacity means the total number of tons of refrigeration installed on one air conditioning system d air conditioning system or air conditioning installation means one or more air conditioning units the water for which passes common meter whether or not the units are owned by the property owner the tenant or a combination of both it is intended that separate submetering for any property owner or tenant occupying different space in the same building could create separate systems  it is not intended that submetering of individual units serving the same space or adjacent space under one owner or tenant would create separate systems e water regulating device means a regulating valve or other device the purpose of which is to limit the maximum use of water to a predetermined rate f water conserving device means a cooling tower spray pound evaporative condenser or other equipment by which the water is cooled and recirculated thereby limiting the use of water from the mains to that amount lost    1950   regulations it is unlawful for any person firm or corporation to have installed or to operate air conditioning or refrigeration equipment without first conforming to the following regulations a permit all water customers who desire to install water utilizing air conditioning or refrigeration equipment are required to submit an application for approval of their equipment and obtain a permit therefor in advance from the city auditor and are required to give notice of completion of such installation to the city water service department the permit charge shall be three dollars for less than three tons capacity of the equipment and six dollars for three tons capacity and over of the equipment b water from city mains all compressor types of air conditioning and refrigeration units having standard rated capacities of less than three tons may be equipped with watercooled condensers using water from city mains provided that not more than one such unit of such capacity and so equipped  or combination of units of such total capacity whether connected singly in series or in parallel  may be used in one air conditioning or refrigeration system c rate of water use  under three ton capacity any system consisting of a unit of less than three tons capacity or a combination of units totaling less than three tons is prohibited from using water from mains in excess of two gallons per minute per ton each unit shall be equipped with an approved automatic water regulating device so adjusted as to limit the use of water under maximum summer conditions to not more than two gallons per minute per ton d rate of water use  over threeton capacity any system consisting of a unit of three tons capacity and over or a combination of units totaling three tons capacity and over is prohibited from using water from the mains in excess of twotenths gallons per minute per ton each such unit or combination of units shall be equipped with a water conserving device the water level control on the tank tower or reservoir shall be so adjusted as to prevent waste of water overflow pipe e existing installations all units installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified herein and contrary thereto shall be converted modified or adjusted to comply as follows 1 installations of less than three tons capacity shall comply with regulation c not later than  2 installations of three tons capacity and over shall comply with regulation d not later than  f inspection the superintendent of the water service department and persons employed by him shall at all reasonable hours have free access to premises supplied with water for airconditioning and refrigeration purposes to examine the equipment and to ascertain if there is more water being used than allowed by this chapter g exemptions none of the foregoing regulations relating to the limiting and regulating the use of water by airconditioning equipment shall apply to churches part 1960 part 1959  1950   penalties for violations any person firm or corporation who violates disobeys omits neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less
